data.title: Can I remove a member from my Organization?
data.content:
Only users with the Admin role can remove other members from the Organization.
 

1. Locate the Member
 
Navigate to the Members page using the left-hand menu. You can find the specific member you wish to remove by:
 
• Scrolling through the list.
• Using the search bar (fuzzy search) to find them by name or email.
• Filtering the list by role (Admin, Member, Billing).
Scrolling through the list.
Using the search bar (fuzzy search) to find them by name or email.
Filtering the list by role (Admin, Member, Billing).
 

2. Initiate Removal
 
Once you have located the member, click the Remove icon associated with their entry in the list.
 
Clicking the 'Remove' icon next to a member's name
 

3. Confirm Removal
 
A confirmation dialog will appear, warning you about the consequences of this action.
 
🚨 Removing a member is permanent. They will immediately lose all access to the Organization, including shared resources and features. If access is needed again later, they will need to be re-invited.
 
🔑 Resources they've created (like Agents or Libraries) won't be deleted and will remain be accessible to your Organization members.
 
To proceed, confirm the removal by clicking the appropriate button in the confirmation dialog (e.g., Remove member).
 
Confirming the removal action in the dialog window
 
The user will then be removed from the Organization members list.
 
 
Any user (Admin, Member, or Billing) can choose to leave an Organization voluntarily, provided they are not the sole remaining Admin of that Organization.
 

1. Locate the Leave Option
 
Navigate to the Members page. Find your own account entry in the list. Click the Remove icon next to your own name.
 
(Note: The icon is the same as the one used by admins to remove others).
 

2. Confirm Departure
 
A confirmation dialog will appear, asking you to confirm that you wish to leave the Organization.
 
🚨 Leaving an Organization is permanent. You will immediately lose all access to that Organization. To rejoin later, an Admin from that Organization must send you a new invitation.
 
To proceed with leaving, confirm your decision in the dialog (e.g., click Leave Organization).
 
Confirming the decision to leave the Organization.
• 
•

data.title: Can Agents access my Connections?
data.content:
Yes, Agents can be configured to access and utilize data from your active Connections (like Gmail, Google Calendar, Google Drive, Microsoft Sharepoint, etc.) directly within le Chat.
 
This capability allows your custom Agents to perform tasks that involve your live, external data sources, such as searching documents, writing emails with a specific tone, or checking your calendar.
 
 
You can grant an Agent permission to use your Connections during its initial creation or by modifying its settings later:
 
• In the Agent configuration screen, navigate to the Knowledge section
• Locate the Connections sub-section where you will find options to select / deselect specific Connections
In the Agent configuration screen, navigate to the Knowledge section
Locate the Connections sub-section where you will find options to select / deselect specific Connections
 
🔎 In case you wish to use new Connections with your Agent, you may need to activate them first. Learn how in this dedicated article.
 
Enable access to your Connections (2) and other knowledge/tools
 
📌 In the same screen, you can authorize your Agent to use specific Tools (1) and enable access to your existing Libraries (3).
 
 
🚨 Please note that Agents can only access one type of data source at a time.
 
Knowledge Connections (such as Google Drive or Microsoft SharePoint) are mutually exclusive at the moment, which mean you can only use one Knowledge Connection per Agent.
 
Similarly, Libraries and Knowledge Connections can't be used together: selecting one will prevent you from selecting the other.
• 
•

data.title: Can Agents access my Libraries?
data.content:
Yes, Agents can be configured to access and utilize the content stored within your Libraries directly within le Chat.
 
This allows your custom Agents to draw upon the specific knowledge contained in documents you've uploaded, making their responses more informed and contextually relevant to your needs.
 
 
You can grant an Agent permission to use one of your Libraries at a time, either during its initial creation or by modifying its settings later:
 
• In the Agent configuration screen, navigate to the Knowledge section
• Locate the Libraries sub-section and select / deselect the Library you want to connect
In the Agent configuration screen, navigate to the Knowledge section
Locate the Libraries sub-section and select / deselect the Library you want to connect
 
💡 Additionaly, you may use the search bar to filter existing Libraries by name to quickly find the one you are looking for.
 
Select your Library (3) in the Knowledge section among your other knowledge/tools (1) and (2)
 
 
🚨 Please note that Agents can only access one type of data source at a time.
 
This means you can only select one Library at a time. Moreover, Libraries and Knowledge Connections (such as Google Drive or Microsoft SharePoint) are mutually exclusive and can't be used together at the moment.
• 
•

data.title: Can I build custom and complex workflows with my Agents?
data.content:
You might be looking to create custom and complex workflows by chaining multiple Agent interactions, triggering sequences of actions, or integrating Agents into broader automated processes.
 
 
Currently, le Chat itself does not offer built-in tools or features for designing and executing complex, multi-step automated workflows without manual intervention in the chat.
 
🔑 Within le Chat interface, Agents are primarily designed to assist you with tasks and provide information and suggestions during your direct, turn-by-turn conversation with them.
 
 
If your goal is to build more complex, automated workflows, you may leverage Mistral AI's agentic capabilities by create an API Agent using the Agent Builder on la Plateforme instead.
 
🔎 For detailed information on creating Agents for API use and interacting with them programmatically, please refer to the official API documentation.
• 
•

data.title: Can I monetize my Agents?
data.content:
You might be considering whether it's possible to monetize Agents that you create using the Mistral AI platform, for instance, by selling access to them or offering them as a commercial service.
 
 
🔑 Currently, Agents created on the Mistral AI platform (whether in le Chat or via the Agent Builder on la Plateforme for API use) are primarily designed for use by you and your organization members.
 
The platform's current sharing and access control mechanisms are focused on internal team collaboration.
 
Therefore, there is no direct feature or supported pathway to share Agents with external users outside of your organization for monetization purposes.
• 
•

data.title: Can I query my le Chat Agent via your APIs?
data.content:
The possibility of an Agent to be queried via our APIs depends on where it was originally created.
 
 
Agents that you create and configure directly within le Chat interface are primarily designed for interactive use within le Chat itself.
 
🔑 They are not directly accessible or queryable via the Mistral AI APIs at this time.
 
 
If your goal is to build an Agent that can be queried programmatically through our APIs, we invite you to use our Agent Builder on la Plateforme instead.
 
🔎 For detailed information on creating Agents for API use and interacting with them programmatically, please refer to the official API documentation.
• 
•

data.title: Can I transfer the ownership of an Agent to another account?
data.content:
You might encounter a situation where you need to transfer the ownership of an Agent you created to another user within your organization.
 
🔑 Directly transferring ownership of an Agent from one user account to another is not a feature that is currently supported on the platform.
 
However, while direct ownership transfer isn't available, you can achieve a similar outcome by granting collaborator access then having the other user duplicate the Agent. Here's how:
 
 
As the current owner, share the Agent with the user you intend to "transfer" it to.
 
🚨 Ensure you grant them Collaborator permissions. This allows them to fully access, use, and edit the Agent's configuration.
 
 
The user with Collaborator access should then duplicate the shared Agent by clicking on the Duplicate my Agent button in the Agent's action menu represented by three dots (⠇).
 
Click on Duplicate my Agent button
 
 
Once the other user has successfully duplicated the Agent and is satisfied with their new copy, you (the original owner) can delete your original Agent if it's no longer needed.
 
📌 This workaround effectively creates a new, independently owned version of the Agent for the other user. Any future modifications to the duplicated Agent will not affect the original and vice-versa.
• 
•

data.title: Do Agents take autonomous decisions or actions on my behalf?
data.content:
When using Agents in le Chat, it's important to understand the scope of their capabilities, particularly regarding decision-making and performing actions.
 
Agents are not autonomous and cannot independently take actions or make decisions on your behalf outside of the direct interaction during your conversation.
 
Agents are designed to:
 
• Assist you with your tasks by processing your requests.
• Provide information, suggestions, and generated content based on their configuration and the instructions you give them.
• Perform tasks directly instructed by you during the conversation (e.g., "draft an email," "summarize this document," "write code for X"), but they do not operate independently beyond that conversational context.
Assist you with your tasks by processing your requests.
Provide information, suggestions, and generated content based on their configuration and the instructions you give them.
Perform tasks directly instructed by you during the conversation (e.g., "draft an email," "summarize this document," "write code for X"), but they do not operate independently beyond that conversational context.
 
🔑 You remain in control and are the sole decision-maker for any actions taken based on the Agent's assistance.
• 
•

data.title: Do I need an active subscription to create Agents?
data.content:
The ability to build, customize, and interact with Agents is a core part of le Chat experience.
 
That’s why we’ve made it available to everyone, whether you’re on the free tier or have an active paid subscription.
 
📌 Important: While a paid subscription is not required to create Agents, you must be logged into your Mistral AI account to use this feature.
• 
•

data.title: How do I chat with an Agent in le Chat?
data.content:
Once you have created or gained access to an Agent, you can easily start interacting with it directly within le Chat.
 
 
In any new or existing conversation in le Chat, simply type the @ symbol in the message input field before you start typing your message.
 
🔑 Typing @ will automatically trigger a list or modal to appear, showing your available Agents.
 
 
From the list that appears, select the name of the Agent you wish to chat with (e.g., My Weather Agent).
 
Type @ to bring up the Agent selection list then select an Agent
 
Once selected, the Agent's name will appear as a mention at the top of your chat box, as seen in the screenshot below:
 
Ensure the mentioned Agent is selected and active for the current conversation
 
 
That's it! With the Agent correctly mentioned and active, simply type your question or request and send your message.
 
Your Agent will process your input and respond according to its configuration and instructions.
 
You may then continue the conversation by sending further messages in the same chat.
 
📌 In case you need to switch to a different Agent, simply repeat the process by typing @ in a new empty message and selecting your new Agent.
 
🔎 See also: How do I stop chatting with an Agent? if you wish to return to the default le Chat model.
• 
•

data.title: How do I delete an Agent?
data.content:
If an Agent you created or administrate is no longer needed, you may remove it permanently from le Chat interface.
 
🔑 Only the creator of an Agent and authorized Collaborators can proceed to its deletion.
 
 
• navigate to the main Agents page in le Chat by clicking Agents in the left-hand menu
• select your Agent card and click on Customize
navigate to the main Agents page in le Chat by clicking Agents in the left-hand menu
select your Agent card and click on Customize
 
Click on Agents on the left-hand menu
 
Click on your Agent card then on Customize.
 
 
• on the Agents page, click on the three vertical dots icon (⠇) to reveal the actions menu
• click on Delete [My Agent Name] where [My Agent Name] is the name of your Agent
• a confirmation dialog will appear, click on Delete to confirm the deletion
on the Agents page, click on the three vertical dots icon (⠇) to reveal the actions menu
click on Delete [My Agent Name] where [My Agent Name] is the name of your Agent
a confirmation dialog will appear, click on Delete to confirm the deletion
 
Click on the three dots ⠇ button then select the delete option
 
Click on Confirm to definitively delete your Agent
 
Your Agent has been successfully deleted. It will no longer be available in le Chat.
 
🚨 Deleting an Agent is an irreversible action. The Agent and its configuration will be permanently removed. If the Agent was shared, it will also become unavailable for all other users who had access to it.
• 
•

data.title: How do I share Agents with my team?
data.content:
Sharing your Agents with other members of your organization is a straightforward process.
 
Here's a step-by-step guide:
 
 
• navigate to the main Agents page in le Chat by clicking Agents in the left-hand menu
• select your Agent card and click on Customize
navigate to the main Agents page in le Chat by clicking Agents in the left-hand menu
select your Agent card and click on Customize
 
Click on Agents on the left-hand menu
 
Click on your Agent card then on Customize.
 
 
Click on the sharing status button, which should either be labeled Private, Organization or Shared with x people alongside a User icon.
 
🔑 By default, a newly created Agent is always Private in le Chat, which means it's only visible to you and usable by you.
 
If you see Organization or Shared with x people it implies that the Agent has already been shared.
 
You may still change revert its status to Private or add more users at your convenience.
 
Clicking the sharing status button (e.g., Private) on an Agent card to open sharing options
 
 
A modal window will appear, allowing you to configure who can access your Agent and what permissions they have.
 
Search and select the users you want to share with and assign them the appropriate permissions as follows:
 
• Collaborators (1): Users or groups added as Collaborators can use the Agent, edit its configuration, and delete it.
• Viewers (2): Users or groups added as Viewers can only use the Agent in their own conversations and can't access its configuration or delete it.
Collaborators (1): Users or groups added as Collaborators can use the Agent, edit its configuration, and delete it.
Viewers (2): Users or groups added as Viewers can only use the Agent in their own conversations and can't access its configuration or delete it.
 
Configuring sharing: Assigning (1) Collaborators and (2) Viewers.
 
📌 You can also share the Agent with everyone in your organization by clicking on the toggle button Entire organization, both as Collaborators or Viewers
 
 
After configuring the desired sharing settings, click Close to exit the sharing modal.
 
The Agent's sharing status on the Agents page will update to reflect its new state (e.g., it might now say Organization if shared with everyone, or indicate the number of people it's shared with, such as Shared with x people) and the icon will update accordingly.
 
Agent card showing the updated sharing (here Organization)
 
Shared Agents can now be accessed and used by the designated team members according to the permissions you've set.
• 
•

data.title: How do I stop chatting with an Agent in a conversation?
data.content:
You can easily revert to the default le Chat model during a conversation by following this simple process:
 
• click on the Agents selector (typically @Your Agent Name) at the top of the chat box to reveal the list of available Agents
• select the default le Chat model
click on the Agents selector (typically @Your Agent Name) at the top of the chat box to reveal the list of available Agents
select the default le Chat model
 
1. Click on the Agent name to select a new Agent
 
2. Select the default le Chat model from the list to deactivate the current Agent
 
Once you've made this change, your subsequent messages in that conversation will immediately be processed by the default le Chat model instead of the Agent you were previously using.
 
📌 Alternatively, if you simply want a clean break from the conversation with the Agent, you might find it easier to start a new chat session. This will begin with the default le Chat model active.
• 
•

data.title: How to write good instructions for my Agent?
data.content:
Crafting effective instructions is key to making your Agent perform as desired. Here are some fundamental tips to help you get started in guiding your Agent.
 
 

Be specific and clear
 
Clearly define the Agent's role, purpose, and the specific tasks you want it to accomplish. Avoid vague or ambiguous language.
 
The more precise your instructions, the better the Agent will understand its designated function.
 

Provide examples
 
If you want the Agent to produce output in a particular format or style, include examples in your instructions.
 
💡 For a summarizing Agent for instance, show an example of a good summary. For something more technical like outputting JSON data, provide a sample JSON structure.
 

Test and refine (Iterate)
 
After providing initial instructions, test your Agent by interacting with it in the preview panel. Observe its responses. If they aren't what you expect, refine your instructions and test again.
 
🔑 Be patient and iterative in this process. It often takes several attempts and adjustments to achieve the desired results.
 
📌 Remember to also leverage the Agent's dedicated settings:
 
• Adjust Tone and Personality: Use the specific fields in the Agent configuration to further guide its conversational style.
• Implement Guardrails: Use guardrails to limit the Agent's responses to certain topics, prevent undesired behaviors, or enforce a particular style.
Adjust Tone and Personality: Use the specific fields in the Agent configuration to further guide its conversational style.
Implement Guardrails: Use guardrails to limit the Agent's responses to certain topics, prevent undesired behaviors, or enforce a particular style.
 
 
Mastering the art of instruction writing (prompt engineering) can significantly enhance your Agent's capabilities.
 
🔎 For more in-depth information and advanced techniques, please see our comprehensive Guide on Prompting Capabilities.
• 
•

data.title: May I speak with multiple Agents in a single conversation?
data.content:
Currently, it is not possible to have multiple Agents active simultaneously or to directly address more than one Agent within the same, single le Chat conversation thread.
 
🔑 Each conversation is typically oriented around interacting with one primary context at a time either the default le Chat model or one specific Agent.
• 
•

data.title: What happens to my Agents if I cancel my subscription?
data.content:
You may decide to cancel your le Chat subscription, effectively reverting to our le Chat free tier.
 
Since Agents is a core le Chat feature and, as such, is not directly tied to a paid subscription, this won't have any impact on your existing Agents.
 
🔑 All your Agents will remain available to you and anyone you have shared them with.
• 
•

data.title: What's an Agent and how do I create one?
data.content:
An Agent is a specialized virtual assistant that you can interact with directly within le Chat or programmatically via APIs.
 
Agents are designed to help you with a variety of tasks, such as answering questions in a specific style or tone, working with documents and integrated knowledge sources, or generating code.
 
 
You can build and customize Agents directly within the le Chat interface.
 

1. Access the Agents page
 
Navigate to the main Agents page in le Chat by clicking Agents in the left-hand menu.
 
Click on Agents on the left-hand menu
 

2. Create a new Agent
 
On the Agents page:
 
• Click the Create Agent button to start building a new Agent from scratch (1).
• Alternatively, select one of the pre-created Agent templates as a starting point for customization (2).
Click the Create Agent button to start building a new Agent from scratch (1).
Alternatively, select one of the pre-created Agent templates as a starting point for customization (2).
 
Options to (1) Create Agent or (2) use a pre-created template
 

3. Configure your Agent
 
You will be taken to the Agent configuration screen.
 
Provide the core details for your Agent as follows:
 
• Name (Required): Give your Agent a unique and descriptive name.
• Description (Optional): Add a brief description of what your Agent does or its intended purpose.
• Avatar (Optional): Choose an avatar for your Agent. You can select from pre-created options or generate a custom one.
• Instructions (Required): Provide clear and detailed instructions for the model (we advise you to consult our dedicated guide for more info: How to write good instructions for my Agent?).
Name (Required): Give your Agent a unique and descriptive name.
Description (Optional): Add a brief description of what your Agent does or its intended purpose.
Avatar (Optional): Choose an avatar for your Agent. You can select from pre-created options or generate a custom one.
Instructions (Required): Provide clear and detailed instructions for the model (we advise you to consult our dedicated guide for more info: How to write good instructions for my Agent?).
 
Configuring Agent: (1) Name, (2) Description, (3) Avatar, (4) Instructions
 

4. Advanced settings (Optional)
 
Besides the strictly required parameters for your Agent, you can refine its behavior further by providing additional settings.
 

Guardrails and Tone/Personality
 
• Add guardrails: Define specific limitations and/or safety protocols for your Agent's responses.
• Adjust tone and personality: Provide additional prompts to fine-tune the Agent's conversational style, tone, and personality traits.Setting (1) Guardrails and (2) Tone/Personality for the Agent.
Add guardrails: Define specific limitations and/or safety protocols for your Agent's responses.
Adjust tone and personality: Provide additional prompts to fine-tune the Agent's conversational style, tone, and personality traits.
Setting (1) Guardrails and (2) Tone/Personality for the Agent.
 

Knowledge and Tools
 
• Grant access to Knowledge and Tools: Enable specific tools for your Agent to use, such as Web search, Code Interpreter, Image Generation, or Canvas (check this article for more info about le Chat capabilities).
• Connect it to your external data sources by selecting active Connections (like Google Drive, Gmail, etc.)
• Connect it to one of your Libraries.
Grant access to Knowledge and Tools: Enable specific tools for your Agent to use, such as Web search, Code Interpreter, Image Generation, or Canvas (check this article for more info about le Chat capabilities).
Connect it to your external data sources by selecting active Connections (like Google Drive, Gmail, etc.)
Connect it to one of your Libraries.
 
Enabling Tools (1), Connections (2), and Libraries (3) for the Agent
 
🔎 Consult these dedicated articles to learn more about Connections and Libraries ⤵️
• What are the Libraries and how do I use them in le Chat?
• Can Agents access my Libraries?
• What are Connections and how do I use them in le Chat?
• Can Agents access my Connections?
What are the Libraries and how do I use them in le Chat?
Can Agents access my Libraries?
What are Connections and how do I use them in le Chat?
Can Agents access my Connections?
 

5. Preview and iterate
 
As you configure your Agent, you can use the preview panel to test its responses and behavior in real-time.
 
Adjust its settings accordingly until you are satisfied with its performance.
 
Testing and previewing the Agent's responses during configuration
 
🔑 You may have noticed that there's no explicit save button. Your Agent is created on the fly and its settings saved automatically as you configure it.
 
Once configured, you can start interacting with your newly created Agent.
 
🔎 For more details, see the article: How do I chat with an Agent in le Chat?
 
 
While you cannot directly create an Agent solely via an API call at this moment, you can use the Agent Builder on la Plateforme to create Agents intended for API deployment.
 
🔎 For detailed information on creating Agents for API use and interacting with them programmatically, please refer to the official API documentation.
 
📌 You can also deploy an Agent created within La Plateforme to le Chat. It will appear in a dedicated section of your Agents list in le Chat. However, for the most integrated and seamless experience when building Agents primarily for use within le Chat, we advise using the new Agent Builder directly withiin le Chat as described above.
• 
•

data.title: Which models can I use with my Agent?
data.content:
When configuring an Agent, the underlying Large Language Model (LLM) that powers its responses may be important depending on your needs.
 
We provide you with two options whether you want to use Agents within le Chat or via our APIs.
 
 
Agents created directly within the le Chat interface are focus on providing a seamless, easy-to-setup and intuitive conversational experience.
 
As such, there is currently no option to select a specific or custom model for Agents built in le Chat.
 
🔑 These Agents are automatically powered by the same latest, high-performance Large Language Models (LLMs) that drive the general le Chat conversational experience.
 
 
On the other hand, Agents created using the Agent Builder on la Plateforme, typically for deployment and use via the API, may need further customization and control over the underlying model.
 
On la Plateforme, you may select a specific Mistral model, or even one of your fine-tuned models to power your Agent.
 
🔑 This allows you to optimize performance, cost, and response quality based on your specific use case.
 
🔎 For detailed information on creating Agents for API use and interacting with them programmatically, please refer to the official API documentation.
• 
•

data.title: Can I customize shortcuts or trigger settings for Mistral Code?
data.content:
Whether you're using the default settings and shortcuts or want to customize your own, both VS Code and JetBrains IDEs got you covered.
 
However, customization process might sometimes get complex depending on your IDE settings.
 
Let's dive into the details step-by-step:
 
 

In VS Code
 
There are various ways to customize shortcuts in VS Code, but the most straightforward way is to use the keyboard shortcuts editor:
 
• Open the Keyboard Shortcuts settings in any of the following ways:Go to File > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on macOS.Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts.Use the shortcuts combination ⌃ + K ⌃ + S / ⌘ + K ⌘ + S. 
• Go to File > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on macOS.
• Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts.
• Use the shortcuts combination ⌃ + K ⌃ + S / ⌘ + K ⌘ + S.
• In the search bar, type the name of the command you want to customize if you know it (e.g., mistralCode.acceptSuggestion) or display all the Mistral Code commands by typing @ext:MistralAI.mistral-code.
• Double-click on the keybinding field to edit it the shortcuts directly, or click on the pencil icon next to it.
• Press the new key combination you want to use and then press Enter.
• Your changes are automatically saved and applied. You can close the editor.
Open the Keyboard Shortcuts settings in any of the following ways:
• Go to File > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on macOS.
• Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts.
• Use the shortcuts combination ⌃ + K ⌃ + S / ⌘ + K ⌘ + S.
Go to File > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Keyboard Shortcuts on macOS.
Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts.
Use the shortcuts combination ⌃ + K ⌃ + S / ⌘ + K ⌘ + S.
 
In the search bar, type the name of the command you want to customize if you know it (e.g., mistralCode.acceptSuggestion) or display all the Mistral Code commands by typing @ext:MistralAI.mistral-code.
Double-click on the keybinding field to edit it the shortcuts directly, or click on the pencil icon next to it.
Press the new key combination you want to use and then press Enter.
Your changes are automatically saved and applied. You can close the editor.
 
📌 If you're an advanced user, you may even use the keybindings.json file to edit the shortcuts directly inside the file.
 
🔎 For more details on how to customize your VS Code settings, check the official documentation.
 

In JetBrains IDEs
 
JetBrains IDEs have their own way of managing keyboard shortcuts:
 
• Open the Keymap settings in any of the following ways:Go to File > Settings... on Windows/Linux (or JetBrains IDE (e.g. WebStorm) > Settings... on macOS).Use the Find action command (⌃ + ⇧ + A on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + A on macOS in the default keymap) then type: Keymap (choose Keymap (Settings)).Use the shortcuts ⌃ + , / ⌘ + ,. 
• Go to File > Settings... on Windows/Linux (or JetBrains IDE (e.g. WebStorm) > Settings... on macOS).
• Use the Find action command (⌃ + ⇧ + A on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + A on macOS in the default keymap) then type: Keymap (choose Keymap (Settings)).
• Use the shortcuts ⌃ + , / ⌘ + ,.
• If applicable, click on Keymap in the left sidebar.
• Search for Mistral Code commands by typing mistral in the search bar.
• Find the command you want to customize (e.g., Add selected code to context).
• Double-click on the shortcut field next to the command. This will open a menu where you can remove the existing shortcut or add a new one.
• Apply the changes by clicking OK at the bottom of the window.
Open the Keymap settings in any of the following ways:
• Go to File > Settings... on Windows/Linux (or JetBrains IDE (e.g. WebStorm) > Settings... on macOS).
• Use the Find action command (⌃ + ⇧ + A on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + A on macOS in the default keymap) then type: Keymap (choose Keymap (Settings)).
• Use the shortcuts ⌃ + , / ⌘ + ,.

data.title: Can I set up project-specific configurations for Mistral Code?
data.content:
The possibility of configuring Mistral Code for specific projects depends on your IDE.
 
 
Besides the default global level, Mistral Code for VS Code settings can be configured either at the workspace level or user level.
 
This means you can set up different configurations for different projects or share configurations across multiple projects.
 
🔎 To learn more about VS Code settings, please refer to the official documentation.
 
 
🚨 At the moment, Mistral Code for JetBrains IDEs does not support project-specific configurations.
• 
•

data.title: Do I need a separate API Key for Mistral Code?
data.content:
Mistral Code extensions require authentication to connect to Mistral AI services via dedicated API calls.
 
This authentication is handled through a specific API key generated automatically upon login, both for VS Code and JetBrains IDEs extensions.
 
This API key is then stored locally on your machine in a config file located in your home directory:
 
• $HOME/.mistralcode/config.json on Linux/macOS
• %USERPROFILE%\.mistralcode\config.json on Windows.
$HOME/.mistralcode/config.json on Linux/macOS
%USERPROFILE%\.mistralcode\config.json on Windows.
 
🚨 This distinct API key, tagged as Mistral Code, will also appear alongside your other Organization's API keys for you to manage. You might delete this API key if needed, but you will then need to generate a new one by starting the login process again from scratch.
• 
•

data.title: Do I need an active subscription to use Mistral Code?
data.content:
🔑 At the moment, Mistral Code is a premium feature only avaible to Enterprise customers.
 
This means that to activate and use Mistral Code, your organization needs to have an active Enterprise agreement with Mistral AI that includes access to this tool.
 
Individual users within such organizations can then log in on their own and use the extension autonomously, provided they've been attributed a Mistral Code seat by their organization's administrator (see 🔎 How to manage Mistral Code seats for more details).
 
Stay tuned for updates on potential changes to this policy.
• 
•

data.title: Do you use my codebase for training your AI models?
data.content:
A primary concern for developers using AI coding assistants is how their proprietary code is handled, specifically whether it's used to train the underlying AI models.
 
 
By default, Enterprise users are opted-out of our AI model training programs.
 
As such, we do not use your codebase (including any code you write or process with Mistral Code), nor your chat interactions, to train or enhance our general-purpose AI models.
 
 
The specifics of data usage and privacy are detailed in the legal agreements and policies governing your use of Mistral Code.
 
For precise terms, please refer to our Terms of Service, or the Enterprise Agreement signed by your organization, when subscribing to the service that includes Mistral Code.
 
🔎 Additional information on our commitment to data privacy and security may also be found in our Trust & Safety articles.
• 
•

data.title: Does Mistral Code store any data on my machine or in the cloud?
data.content:
Yes, when you use the Mistral Code extension/plugin, certain data is stored both locally on your machine and potentially in the cloud as part of its operation and for service improvement. Understanding what data is stored and where is important.
 
 
During usage, Mistral Code creates a dedicated folder in your user's home directory to store files necessary for the extension to function correctly. The typical locations are:
 
• macOS: ~/.mistralcode
• Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.mistralcode
• Linux: /home/<user>/.mistralcode
macOS: ~/.mistralcode
Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.mistralcode
Linux: /home/<user>/.mistralcode
 
This folder may contain various types of files, including but not limited to:
 
• Log files: for troubleshooting and recording extension activity.
• Index files: local caching / indexing of project information to speed up responses.
• Configuration files: storing settings and authentication tokens (like API keys).
• Cache and session files: temporary files used to improve performance and maintain your session state (including chat history).
Log files: for troubleshooting and recording extension activity.
Index files: local caching / indexing of project information to speed up responses.
Configuration files: storing settings and authentication tokens (like API keys).
Cache and session files: temporary files used to improve performance and maintain your session state (including chat history).
 
🔑 The data stored in this local folder is primarily for the extension's operational use and to enhance your user experience and shoudn't typically be modified by hand.
 
🚨 Additionaly, please be aware that this data is not encrypted by the extension and could be read by anyone with direct access to your machine or user profile.
 
 
To provide AI-powered assistance, Mistral Code needs to communicate with Mistral AI's cloud services.
 
This involves sending data such as your code snippets (the context around your cursor or selected code) or your natural language queries typed into the chat interface.
 
The handling of this data in the cloud, including retention policies and usage for service improvement, is governed by the terms you agreed to.
 
🔎 You may find more general information (such as how long or where do we store your data) in our various Data Governance articles.
• 
•

data.title: How can I assign Mistral Code seats to my team members?
data.content:
As an administrator of your Organization, you may assign seats to your team members one by one, allowing them to use Mistral Code effectively.
 
🔑 Please note before proceeding that Mistral Code is a premium feature at the moment: your organization must have an Enterprise subscription plan that includes Mistral Code seats.
 
 
If you are an Admin, you may assign new seats or manage existing assignments for Mistral Code through the Mistral AI Admin Console:
 

1. Navigate to the Members Panel of your Admin Console
 
On the main page, click on Members in the left-hand navigation menu to access the user management area.
 
Clicking Members in the left menu to access the Members admin panel
 

2. Locate your user and manage seats
 
On the Members page within the Admin Console, you will see a list of users in your organization.
 
Find the user to whom you want to assign a Mistral Code seat (you may filter the list of users by their name, email, or other criteria using the filters at the top of the page).
 
For each user, locate the Mistral Code column where you will set the seat assignment to Active or Inactive.
 
The Mistral Code column where you can assign seats to users
 
Once a user is assigned a Mistral Code seat, they should be able to log in to the Mistral Code extension/plugin in their IDE of choice (VS Code or JetBrains) and start using its features effectively.
 
🔎 Note that you may also directly assign seats upon user invitation. For a more detailed walkthrough of this process, please refer to our dedicated article: How can I invite new members and assign seats?
• 
•

data.title: How can I monitor Mistral Code usage in my Organization?
data.content:
As an Admin of your Organization, it may be useful to monitor the usage of services like Mistral Code to manage your subscription effectively and understand team adoption.
 
 
You can track Mistral Code utilization by navigating to the dedicated usage monitoring page on la Plateforme.
 
🔑 This page is specifically designed to provide insights into the usage related to Mistral Code (not le Chat or API usage). Both models used in Mistral Code (Codestral & Mistral Medium 3) are tracked indifferently.
 
You will find various monthly-tracked data points, including but not limited to:
 
• Number of active users
• Numbers of requests per user
• Number of tokens generated per user
Number of active users
Numbers of requests per user
Number of tokens generated per user
 
By regularly reviewing this dedicated usage page, you can stay informed about how Mistral Code is being utilized within your organization, manage your budget, and make informed decisions about seat allocation and feature adoption.
•

data.title: How do I install the Mistral Code extension for VS Code?
data.content:
The Mistral Code extension integrates AI-assisted coding features directly into Visual Studio Code (VS Code).
 
Installation is straightforward and can be done in a few simple steps:
 
 

1. Open Vs Code
 
Launch VS Code on your computer, where you want to install Mistral Code.
 

2. Access the extensions marketplace
 
You can open the Extensions marketplace in any of the following ways:
 
• Go to File > Settings... > Extensions on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Extensions on macOS.
• Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Extensions: Install Extensions.
• Use the shortcuts ⌃ + ⇧ + X / ⌘ + ⇧ + X
Go to File > Settings... > Extensions on Windows/Linux, or Code > Settings... > Extensions on macOS.
Use the Command Palette (⌃ + ⇧ +P on Windows/Linux or ⌘ + ⇧ + P on macOS) then type: Extensions: Install Extensions.
Use the shortcuts ⌃ + ⇧ + X / ⌘ + ⇧ + X
 

3. Search for Mistral Code
 
In the Extensions view search bar, type Mistral Code Enterprise.
 

4. Install the Extension
 
Locate the official Mistral Code Enterprise extension (by Mistral AI) in the search results.
 
Click the Install button next to it.
 
📌 VS Code will download and install the extension automatically.
 
 
You can also install the Mistral Code extension directly from its page on the Visual Studio Marketplace:
 
• Open your web browser and navigate to the Mistral Code extension page: Mistral Code - VS Code Marketplace
• On the Marketplace page, click the Install button. This will usually prompt your browser to open the link with VS Code, which will then proceed with the installation.
Open your web browser and navigate to the Mistral Code extension page: Mistral Code - VS Code Marketplace
On the Marketplace page, click the Install button. This will usually prompt your browser to open the link with VS Code, which will then proceed with the installation.
 
 
Lastly, you can install the Mistral Code extension directly from the Mistral Code page on la Plateforme.
 
Steps are then the same as in Method 2.
 
 
Once the installation is complete:
 
• You should see a Mistral Code icon appear in the Activity Bar on the left-hand side of your VS Code window.
• Click the Mistral Code icon to open the Mistral Code panel.
• You will be prompted to log in to your Mistral AI account. See the article 🔎 How do I log in to Mistral Code in VS Code? for details.
You should see a Mistral Code icon appear in the Activity Bar on the left-hand side of your VS Code window.
Click the Mistral Code icon to open the Mistral Code panel.
You will be prompted to log in to your Mistral AI account. See the article 🔎 How do I log in to Mistral Code in VS Code? for details.
 
You are now ready to start using Mistral Code to enhance your coding workflow in VS Code!

data.title: How do I log in to Mistral Code in JetBrains IDEs?
data.content:
After installing the Mistral Code plugin in your JetBrains IDE (like IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, etc.), you need to log in with your Mistral AI account to activate its features.
 
The process for JetBrains IDEs involves an API key exchange.
 
 

1. Open Mistral Code
 
Locate the Mistral Code plugin in the Tool Window Bar (typically located on the right, left, or bottom edge of your JetBrains IDE window) and click the Mistral Code icon.
 

2. Initiate login process
 
In the Mistral Code panel, click the Open Mistral Code Page button as shown in the screenshot below.
 
Click on the Open Mistral Code Page button
 

3. Log in to Mistral AI platform via browser
 
This action will open a new tab or window in your default web browser, directing you to Mistral AI authentication flow if you're unauthenticated.
 
🚨 You should log in with an Enterprise account that has access to Mistral Code otherwise you won't be able to access the API key page.
 

4. Retrieve your API Key
 
After successfully logging in, the webpage should display an API Key created specifically for your Mistral Code usage in JetBrains IDEs.
 
If needed, you can display the key, generate a new API key or even delete it (be sure to have at least one valid Mistral Code API key to complete the login process).
 
Copy the API key
 

5. Enter API key in your JetBrains IDE
 
• Return to your JetBrains IDE and enter the API key you copied from the Mistral Code webpage to the input field in the Mistral Code panel (1).
• Then click on the Login button (2).
Return to your JetBrains IDE and enter the API key you copied from the Mistral Code webpage to the input field in the Mistral Code panel (1).
Then click on the Login button (2).
 
Paste the API key (1) then click on the Login button (2)
 
🔑 This process is only required once. Your API key will be stored locally on your machine. However, logging out will remove this API key definitively and you will need to repeat the process from scratch upon next login.
 

6. Login confirmation
 
The plugin will validate the API key with Mistral AI servers.
 
Upon successful validation of the API key, the plugin should now display the chat interface.
 
You can verify that you are logged in with an active subscription by checking in the User Account tab (1) and eventually Logout (2) when needed.
 
Mistral Code chat interface
 
That's it! You are now ready to use Mistral Code in your JetBrains IDE.

data.title: How do Mistral Code suggestions integrate with version control tools such as Git?
data.content:
Mistral Code is designed to assist you in writing and modifying code, and these changes can be seamlessly integrated into your existing version control workflows, such as those using Git.
 
 
Code suggested or generated by Mistral Code becomes part of your project files as long as you accept the suggestions and save your files.
 

1. Direct code completion
 
When Mistral Code provides code completion suggestions as you type, accepting these suggestions (e.g., by pressing Tab or a specific accept key) directly inserts the suggested code into your active file.
 
🔑 These suggestions are not staged or committed by default until you explicitly do so using your IDE's or Git's tools.
 

2. Code generation via the chat interface
 
When you use the Mistral Code chat panel to request code generation (e.g., "write a Python function to sort a list"), the AI will provide the code directly within the chat.
 
You can then typically use buttons like Apply to file, Insert at cursor, or a simple copy/paste action to transfer this generated code into your desired file and location.
 
🔑 Once the code from Mistral Code is incorporated into your files, it becomes just like any other code you've written manually and can be staged and committed using your usual Git commands (e.g., git add and git commit)
 
 
Additionaly, Mistral Code offers the /commit command that you may use directly within the Chat interface, both in VS Code and JetBrains IDEs extensions.
 
🔑 This command can generate a ready-to-use commit message based on your currently staged changes, helping you write clear and consistent commit messages more quickly.
• 
•

data.title: How does Mistral Code handle multi-file projects and context?
What are the available commands and shortcuts in Mistral Code, and how do they work?
data.content:
Mistral Code is designed to enhance your coding workflow by providing intelligent assistance directly within your development environment. It offers a variety of commands and shortcuts to streamline interactions and improve productivity.
 
 
Mistral Code offers several convenient slash commands that you can type directly into its chat interface to perform specific actions quickly.
 
Here are the currently available commands for every IDE:
 

/commit (VS Code & JetBrains IDEs)
 
• Purpose: Automatically generates a concise and contextually relevant commit message based on the changes you have staged in your Git repository.
• How it works:First, you need to stage the changes you want to include in the commit using your Git client (e.g., by running git add . or staging files through your IDE's Git interface).In the Mistral Code chat interface, type /commit.Mistral Code will analyze your staged changes and propose a commit message.You can then review, edit if necessary, and use this message for your Git commit. 
• First, you need to stage the changes you want to include in the commit using your Git client (e.g., by running git add . or staging files through your IDE's Git interface).
• In the Mistral Code chat interface, type /commit.
• Mistral Code will analyze your staged changes and propose a commit message.
• You can then review, edit if necessary, and use this message for your Git commit.
• Benefit: Helps maintain a clean, consistent, and informative commit history with minimal effort.

• First, you need to stage the changes you want to include in the commit using your Git client (e.g., by running git add . or staging files through your IDE's Git interface).

In the Mistral Code chat interface, type /commit.
Mistral Code will analyze your staged changes and propose a commit message.
You can then review, edit if necessary, and use this message for your Git commit.
 
Benefit: Helps maintain a clean, consistent, and informative commit history with minimal effort.
 

/cmd - Generate shell command (VS Code only)
 
• Purpose: Allows you to describe a task in natural language, and Mistral Code will generate the corresponding shell command (e.g., for Bash, PowerShell, etc.).
• How it works:In the Mistral Code chat interface, type /cmd followed by a description of the command you need (e.g., /cmd list all files in the current directory including hidden ones).Mistral Code will provide the shell command that accomplishes your described task (e.g. ls -a on Linux/Mac or dir /a on Windows).Command is automatically copied into your terminal, waiting for your explicit confirmation (Enter) before running. 
• In the Mistral Code chat interface, type /cmd followed by a description of the command you need (e.g., /cmd list all files in the current directory including hidden ones).
• Mistral Code will provide the shell command that accomplishes your described task (e.g. ls -a on Linux/Mac or dir /a on Windows).
• Command is automatically copied into your terminal, waiting for your explicit confirmation (Enter) before running.
• Benefit: Useful for quickly finding the right command for less common tasks or for remembering complex command syntax.

Mistral Code will provide the shell command that accomplishes your described task (e.g. ls -a on Linux/Mac or dir /a on Windows).
Command is automatically copied into your terminal, waiting for your explicit confirmation (Enter) before running.
 
Benefit: Useful for quickly finding the right command for less common tasks or for remembering complex command syntax.
 
🚨 The /cmd command is currently not available in JetBrains IDEs.
 

/share - Export Chat Session (VS Code & JetBrains IDEs)
 
• Purpose: Enables you to export your current chat conversation with Mistral Code into a portable format.
• How it works:In the Mistral Code chat/input, type /share.Mistral Code will typically generate a Markdown (.md) representation of your current chat session.You can then copy this Markdown content to save it, share it with colleagues, use it for documentation, or even as data for fine-tuning your own models. 
• In the Mistral Code chat/input, type /share.

• You can then copy this Markdown content to save it, share it with colleagues, use it for documentation, or even as data for fine-tuning your own models.
• Benefit: Makes it easy to document solutions, share interactions for troubleshooting, or keep records of important AI-assisted coding sessions.

data.title: What are the system requirements for running Mistral Code extensions on VS Code and JetBrains IDEs?
data.content:
Mistral Code extensions are designed to operate efficiently within the environments provided by Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) and JetBrains IDEs.
 
Therefore, if your system can comfortably run the latest stable version of VS Code or your chosen JetBrains IDE, it should generally be capable of running the Mistral Code extension as well.
 
And since model inference isn't done locally, consumer-grade computers are sufficient to run Mistral Code.
 
🚨 Additionaly, note that you will also need a stable internet connection for the extension to communicate with Mistral AI services for both authentication and to provide AI-powered assistance via our APIs.
• 
•

data.title: What models power Mistral Code?
data.content:
Mistral Code leverages specialized, high-performance models from Mistral AI to provide its advanced coding assistance features.
 
The choice of model is tailored to the specific task being performed by the extension.
 
 

Code completions
 
Mistral Code primarily uses Codestral for its sophisticated FIM capabilities.
 
Codestral is Mistral AI's specialized code model, specifically designed and optimized for code generation tasks, including infilling code, completing code blocks, and understanding programming languages deeply.
 
🔎 Learn more about Codestral and its capabilities on the Mistral AI Blog.
 

Chat completions
 
For conversational interactions, code explanation, generating code from descriptions, refactoring suggestions, and other chat-based assistance, Mistral Code utilizes our latest powerful and versatile model Mistral Medium 3.
 
Mistral Medium 3 is designed for a wide range of complex reasoning and generation tasks, making it well suited for understanding developer queries and providing helpful, context-aware responses.
 
🔎 Discover more about Mistral Medium 3 on the Mistral AI Blog.
 
 
📌 Currently, there is no option to select or use custom fine-tuned models directly within the Mistral Code extension or plugin. The extension is optimized to use the specific Mistral AI models mentioned above to ensure the best performance and integration for its features.
 
By employing these specialized models, Mistral Code aims to deliver a high-quality, responsive, and intelligent coding assistance experience.
• 
•

data.title: What programming languages does Mistral Code support?
data.content:
You may be wondering which language is natively supported by Mistral Code extensions (both for VS Code and JetBrains IDEs).
 
 
Mistral Code is fundamentally designed to be language-agnostic. This means it aims to provide assistance for code completion, generation, explanation, and other features across a wide variety of programming languages.
 
🔑 The extension dynamically adapts to the language context of the file you are currently editing. It strives to provide relevant suggestions and AI-powered assistance tailored to the specific syntax and conventions of that programming language.
 
Whether you are working with popular languages like Python, JavaScript, Java, C++, Go, Rust, TypeScript, or many others, Mistral Code got you covered.
 
 
The underlying models powering Mistral Code are continuously being trained and improved, which includes enhancing their understanding and generation capabilities across an ever-expanding set of programming languages.
 
If you encounter a specific programming language where you feel Mistral Code support could be relevant, or if there's a language you frequently use that you'd like to see better supported, please contact our support team to provide your feedback.
 
🔎 You may also join us on our various developer community channels, such as our official Discord server.
 
Thank you for helping us make Mistral Code even better!
• 
•

data.title: What's Mistral Code and how may it help me as a developer?
data.content:
Mistral Code is our AI-powered coding assistant designed to integrate directly into your development environment and boost your productivity across various coding tasks.
 
It leverages advanced large language models to understand code and provides intelligent assistance.
 
🔑 Currently, Mistral Code is available as a VS Code extension and a JetBrains plugin for our premium Enterprise customers. Stay tuned for more integrations or opening to other plans!
 
Here are some of the key capabilities Mistral Code offers:
 
 
Mistral Code can provide you with blazing fast code completions, based on the context of your current code, from single lines to entire blocks of code.
 
When you start typing, it will automatically suggest completions that match your coding style and the project's conventions, waiting for you to accept or modify them.
 
 
Leverage Mistral Code interactive chat interface to design and generate code from simple snippets to entire files from scratch, using only natural language descriptions in context.
 
 
Familiar with one language but need to write in another?
 
Mistral Code can translate your code from one programming language to another, helping you quickly adapt and reuse existing logic or samples you found online.
 
 
Whether you want to grasp a new codebase or simply need to understand a specific function, Mistral Code can explain code in plain English, allowing you to deep dive into the logic and functionality at your own pace.
 
 
Mistral Code can help you with various tedious tasks, such as renaming variables or functions, extracting methods, inlining code, and more, helping you improve code structure and maintainability.
 
 
With its deep understanding of code, and direct access to your IDE's console and output logs, Mistral Code can analyze error messages and suggest fixes, helping you identify and resolve issues more efficiently. It can also explain error messages in plain English, making it easier to understand what went wrong.
 
 
Testing is a crucial part of development, but more often than not, it is a tedious task. Mistral Code can help you with that.
 
Start generating your tests in your own style in no time, helping you ensure code quality and robustness!
 
 
No time for writing documentation? Mistral Code is here to help. It can help you generate documentation for your code, such as docstrings, comments, or even drafting README.md files based on the codebase.
 
📌 Even the documentation you're reading right now was generated by Mistral Code!
 
 
With its deep understanding of your codebase and the changes you've made, Mistral Code can help you generate commit messages that are concise, informative, and follow best practices.
 
The /commit command will generate a commit message based on your staged changes, and you can edit it before committing.
 
No more generic commit messages like "fix bug" or "update code"!
 
 
Let's be honest, we all have our favorite shell commands, but sometimes we forget them, or we don't know the exact syntax.
 
Mistral Code can generate shell commands for you, based on your current context, or based on your natural language description and copy it directly to your terminal, waiting for you to run it.
 
No more man sed or stackoverflow tedious searches!
 
🔑 This feature is currently available solely in the VS Code extension.
 
 
Mistral Code is constantly evolving, and we're always adding new features and capabilities to make your development experience even better.
 
🔎 Eager to start? Check the following articles to install and get started with Mistral Code! ⤵️
• Install Mistral Code in VS Code
• Install Mistral Code in JetBrains IDEs
Install Mistral Code in VS Code
Install Mistral Code in JetBrains IDEs
